text: I could never imagine a way to make money from the things I want to build. Was their ever a time when you could sell a compiler for a novel language? These days it's quite a hard sell just getting people to try it.

text: <@UD6EXQVM0> that'd be a great thread for <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together>. I invite you to repost it there. My short answer is: yes, but the skills of product design and marketing are disciplines unto themselves, as nuanced and broad as programming. I'm sure lots of other folks have a differing opinion, so let's have a thread on it!

. I invite you to repost it there. My short answer is: yes, but the skills of product design and marketing are disciplines unto themselves, as nuanced and broad as programming. I'm sure lots of other folks have a differing opinion, so let's have a thread on it!

text: Well, Jeff was checking if anyone is starting companies, but only people with business models can start companies, so I'm pointing out that most of us probably don't have one (and I myself tend to be attracted to problems that capitalism has failed to solve). Because it's an important problem in this space that is not discussed enough. (It seems like a business model hasn't been a hard requirement from VCs in the last decade, but if you don't have a proper money-making plan, you at least need to build something that can be plausibly monetized someday, e.g. a large online community; also, by now, VCs/investors have probably learned to be more skeptical of companies without business models.) Why do you mention marketing and product design?
